reviewText:
SUPER GALAXY SQUADRON
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Super Galaxy Squadron is one of the best retro Arcade Shoot’Em up games I have had the pleasure to play for quite a while.

Lovers of retro games will be fond of this one and if you are of a certain age (like Yoda and me), you will experience a trip back to memory lane where all good games were setup like a booth with an old television set right in front of you, a stick on the left hand side of the panel with a fairly large red ball for a good and stable grip. And 2 buttons on the right side which were usually red and yellow. Too bad if you were right handed, impossible to play with your back facing the television set!

Coming back to the game, you can choose to play a new, endless or continue a game in normal or hardcore mode. Then, you have to make the tough decision as to which spaceship you are going to fight with. Fourteen to choose from; some have more power than others and so on and so forth. All spaceships have their own Hyper strike if you want to call it that, again some more effective than others.

After that it’s all about avoiding the onslaught of your enemies’ fire power like some sort of illusionist and at the same time destroying them with your powerful arsenal! I FUN FUN FUN! Mind you, the hardcore mode is fairly challenging.

In term of the controls, I find the gamepad the way to go rather than your keyboard. It is just my preference.

Positives:
~~~~~~~

-	Great Shoot’Em Up
-	Challenging
-	Achievements
-	Trading cards

Negative:
~~~~~~~

-	I feel older now

Good game.

9/10

reviewText:
This key was obtained from evolve.pr for the purposes of review.

Target Audience:   Action oriented fans that want twitch reactionary gameplay...even if you're not a veteran of the SHMUP genre.

Video Review:   https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-GT56CIRT-c

Summary:
Not only is Super Galaxy Squadron EX pretty solid across the board, it's one of best “remasterings” for an indie game that I've seen. The game has been turned up to 11, as the game is not only pretty to look at, but it has ramped up the enemies and challenge in several ways. The developer obviously took feedback from the original game, as UI changes makes things a lot easier to see, and it complements the strong action gameplay that has the controls necessary to get through the tight spaces in between bullet barrages. There's a lot of ship variety as well, although the number of bullet patterns do leave a bit to be desired. And the game, while it was in Early Access, seems to still have a mode that's “coming soon”, which offput me a tiny bit. But never the less, A great shmup for the price of admission here, and can not only help satisfy the SHMUP veteran, but is a good introductory game for those who want to try the genre out for the first time. All in All, a worthy purchase.


Lists:
+:
Good basic SHMUP action. Throws everything and the kitchen sink at you, and when things get nuts, things get nuts.
Controls are where they need to be. Gives you the precision to get through the onslaught of bullets that you need, without being overly sensitive.
Great presentation and aesthetic. The story presentation does the scifi theme well, but the color choices for bullets/ships was smartly put together. It's easy to see everything on the field, and it's clear that the developers understood how to complement game design with aesthetic.
Good accessibility for new players of the genre, but gives the challenge for SHMUP veterans as well.
A good variety of ships. A lot of different strategies are viable because of the variety here, from close up in your face “melee” type damage to turtling damage and focusing on hitting powerful enemies. Some may feel similar in the end, but there is a level of detail that does separate the similar ships from each other.
Like the weapon powerups system and how getting hit makes you drop a couple of them. Forces quick decision making as being bombarded with bullets could lead you to abandoning the power ups because of the additional damage and power ups that you'd lose.
A good example of a remastering: changing some slight mechanics in game play, upping the graphics
Decent soundtrack. Complements the scifi and gameplay rather well.
-:
Lacking some basic options. A music slider? That seems like a standard  now a days, and no bindable keys as well. Disappointing.
Could actually use a bit more variety in the bullet patterns area. Within the first few levels, it's thrown pretty much all the different patterns at you, it just throws MORE at you.
Despite coming out of early access, there's still a mode that seems to be unfinished. This is a personal gripe: if you're part of early access, I expect a completed product if you're going to come out of it.

reviewText:
I bought Super Galaxy Squadron based mostly on the excellent art, music, and the fact that it looked like it might offer some good challenge and design.  I am so incredibly disappointed.

The game is not without merits.  The visuals are great. The music is nice.  The audio is superb, with great sounds as you blow up enemy ships.  There are even some good mechanics.  Shooting missiles during boss fights to refill hyper gauge is great fun (and the bosses have destructible parts, hooray!).  There's a bunch of ships to choose from.  Lots of good stuff going on here.

All of those good elements are what leave me feeling so utterly baffled by this game.  It's got so many of the elements necessary to make a really fun shoot em up, yet it's plagued with a host of amateur-hour mistakes.  The developers clearly understand many of the things that make shmups so much fun, so why all the mistakes that even a rookie shmupper would be appalled by?

First problem is the terrible control scheme.  To begin with, there is no control remapping, or even several schemes available.  I wanted to play on the same arcade stick I use for every game, but the dpad isn't supported as a movement option, and the buttons are mapped with a controller in mind, so if I wanted to use Hyper attacks, I'd be reaching across to my shoulder buttons on stick.  As if the lack of control customization wasn't baffling enough, SGS uses analog controls.  For players unfamiliar with shmups and why this is a problem, remember that this is a genre about precision and lots of small movements.  With analog controls, that precision is flung out of the window, since two taps of the stick can be yield different results based on how far you moved the stick.  With digital controls, it's entirely based on how long  you hold the stick, giving you fewer variables to deal with when moving, and ultimately lending the game greater control.  Without this, SGS feels like a sloppy mess.

SGS also has obnoxiously sturdy enemies.  Even the basic popcorns can't be taken down in a single hit, and the larger enemies can sustain fire for ridiculous lengths.  It's extremely frustrating, leading to a lot of sitting in one area, waiting for that needlessly tanky enemy to go down.  Bosses are what really exemplify this, with them lasting absurd, huge lengths of time, repeating the same handful of patterns over and over while you slowly drift into sleep.

I also encountered a few other horrible design choices.  The second level is full of asteroids floating down to hit you.  Unfortunately, there are also harmless asteroids in the background.  The difference between the two was a fairly subtle change in the color of brown, so it was extremely difficult to know at a glance if an asteroid would kill me or not.  Asteroids?  Fine.  Background asteroids?  Fine.  Both at once?  Horrific.

Another awful little problem I noticed was on the second boss, who fired a huge laser.  No biggy.  I dodged it.  Only then the laser kept firing for an extremely long period of time as the boss slooooowly drifted towards me, completely trapping me on the side of the screen where I was forced to eat the laser.  Impossible to dodge unless you know in advance that the laser is going to fire for ages. (Or maybe I was supposed to shoot the laser to break it?  Seems unlikely, since breakable parts take hours to destroy).

Either way, I don't think I'll ever learn the mystery of how to avoid the 10-hour laser, since immediately after dying, the game glitched and refused to respawn my ship.  Lovely.

If you're looking for a fun shmup on steam, give this a pass.  There are far better choices out there. (Crimzon Clover, Ikaruga, The Alltynex Trilogy, Satazius, Jamestown, etc).  Super Galaxy Squadron may look and sound nice, but that's really all its got going for it.

Most games in this genre devote very little effort to storytelling, and while I wouldn't exactly call SGS a story-heavy game, I found myself getting into the world/story far more than I do with typical shmups.  My favorite touch was the couple sentences of backstory provided for each of the 14 playable ships on the ship select screen; amazing how much depth that adds to the game's world.

The soundtrack, created by Random Encounter, is fantasic, though it would've benefited from a couple more tracks. (Finish the game for an extra special version of the title theme~)

The game plays very tight and is filled with beautfiul, crisp 16-bit sprites. The difficulty curve feels just about perfect although veteran shmup players will probably be bored for the first few stages.

This is a symptom of the one real problem I had with the game: the lack of a deep scoring system. Typically shmups feature some sort of complex scoring dynamic that calls for some specific strategy to maximize your scoring (for example the spectacular Vaunt" scoring system in Jamestown); this gives higher skill players something to go for on easier stages where survival isn't really a concern. SGS sports a very simple combo system that rewards you for killing enemies in quick succession (before your combo meter resets).  Unfortunately
date: the player really has very little control over maintaining a combo due to the way the enemies spawn and ultimately most players will end up ignoring the combo meter entirely. Even something as simple as being able to slow down or freeze your combo meter by letting go of the fire button would make going for high scores much more interesting.\n\nDespite the lack of scoring depth
recommended: I'd still highly recommend this to anyone remotely interested in a good arcadey experience.  This game's difficulty makes more accessible than the average shmup a is great bridge to more difficult games like Ikaruga and Gradius."

The updated art and the little cutscenes between stages have brought this game a long way forward. A lot of my previous concerns like the music not looping cleanly appears to have been fixed as well. Old review for Super Galaxing Squadron classic:

Super Galaxy Squadron is not bad, but it's less than what I expected it to be.

Normal Mode is not a big challenge as it feels like the life bar lasts forever (I reached the stage 6 boss second form on the first try and cleared the game on the 2nd attempt), while in Hardcore mode from what I could tell if you get hit once you have to start the level over. I think my skill level is probably more at a middle ground between the two, but the game doesn't offer this.

The art is nice but I only noticed 1 enemy ship (pink one) which was actually animated. The music was decent but not very memorable. Only the title screen music and the stage 6 music stood out for me, although some of the music did not loop naturally.

The power up system wasn't fun for me. The power ups dropped by enemies don't fall down to you, they just kind of sit there and move a small amount before fading away. If you get hit you will also usually lose one of your powerups, which fly upwards and can't be picked up again for a couple of seconds. The tried and true hyper system is fine though and the ships do feel a bit different from each other, although I only tried a handful of them.

However, the worst part about the game is the bosses. The boss patterns are boring. Aside from the stage 5 and 6 bosses, the rest just repeat the one pattern over and over. The stage 6 boss was the best out of all, and although I did feel like I had seen the patterns before in other games, I liked it and wished the same attention had been given to the other bosses as well.

I found the most enjoyment in endless mode, since I was able to zone out and fly around shooting things and dodging bullets, without having to face any of the bosses.

In all, I would say that the game is worth a try. You may like it more than I did. But it's not something I can see myself coming back to or getting friends to play.

reviewText:
Bullet Hell games, So called because there's a lot of bullets and it feels like hell. It likely comes as no surprise then that these games can be pretty elitist. Searching online you'll find no end of videos of people managing to stay in the one exact pixel of safety on a screen so filled with moving things and colour that half the time you can't even tell where the ship is. What most people are after however is something more casual, or rather something that doesn't need reflexes akin to a cheetah on 10 cans of Red Bull. And along comes Super Galaxy Squadron EX.

Super Galaxy Squadron isn't actually a new game. It was released just over a year ago and EX is somewhere between a Remaster and an expansion. What's changed? Just about everything! It's a real do over. Everything has been made to look better, gauges and icons have been added to help you keep better track of your health and power levels. New enemies, better level designs and actual story!

Where Super Galaxy Squadron EX stands above other games is in two main ways; It's difficulty curve allowing  new players to be eased into a difficult genre and it's ship selection. I can't stress how important that new player experience is. If you like bullet hell games then you already know what you're after and what you're looking for. But if you don't? Then Super Galaxy Squadron EX is just what you need.

The different ships also allow for a variety of play styles. Whilst the core mechanic of 'hold down the fire button and move out of the way of all the dangerous things' stays the same the variations in the ships means you can change things up fairly dramatically. You might want a slow ship that packs a massive punch and can take a fair few hits or you might prefer a super fast, low damage ship where you do more dodging and only take down key targets. You can change your ship at the start of a mission so you can take on different missions in different ways.

The base game was pretty good. EX has made everything that much better, it could easily be Super Galaxy Squadron 2 and I don't think anyone would have been angry. But instead it's been released as a free upgrade to the original game! Whilst it's maybe not for diehard Bullet Hell fans for a first entry into a genre there isn't much of a better choice.
